Award.AwardTitle: Towards a data-based and physics-based model of interseismic and seismic behavior of Main Himalayan Thrust
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Himalaya stands out as the major threat with respect to seismic hazard in central Asia where it puts at risk the dense population and economies of several countries. The project will contribute important information regarding seismic activity in that area and, more generally, will advance methods regarding the use of geodetic measurements in seismic hazard studies.

Recent and historical earthquakes in the Himalaya fall way short of balancing the rate at which interseismic strain is currently accumulating in the Himalaya. Thus we have a very incomplete view of how interseismic strain is released by transient seismic, and possibly, aseismic slip on the Main Himalayan Thrust fault. The long term objective of this project is the development of a dynamic model and the acquisition of appropriate data to validate and calibrate the model that will allow assessing the full range of possible earthquake scenarios in the Himalaya and their probability of occurrence. To achieve that goal we propose (1) to keep on monitoring and improve the modeling of interseismic coupling on the MHT, (2) use dynamic modeling to evaluate the fault frictional properties needed to account for the observed pattern of interseismic coupling, the sensitivity of seismicity to secular and seasonal stress build up an (3) use dynamic models to test how the statistics of small earthquakes triggered by stress build up at downdip edge of the locked portion of the MHT can be used to constrain the statistics of the very large events rupturing the whole locked zone (4) constrain the viscous properties of the crust based on the geodetically measured deformation induced by surface load variations measured from the GRACE gravimetric satellite mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Title: Toward a physics-based and data-based model of the seismic cycle in the Himalaya


This grant provided support for the maintenance of the GPS network that had been deployed in Nepa, under a collaboration with the Departement of Mines and Geoogy of Nepal  Nepal with funding from Caltech and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.The geodetic data were used to track slip along the Main Himalayan Thrust (MHT) fault along which the Himlayan wedge is thrust over India. We showed that, in the ‘intersesimic’ period separating large earthquakes the Main Himalayan Thrust is quasi uniformly locked over a width of ~120 km, and accumulating elastic strain, along the entire Himalayan arc. We derived implications for the magnitude and return period of the largest plausible earthquake in the Himalaya and concluded that Mw ~9.0 or larger events with a ~1000yr return period are likely and quantified the corresponding likeliness.

Funding from this grant was  used to support the retrieval of GPS records  following the Mw 7.8, 2015 Gorkha earthquake of April 25, 2015. The high rate GPS data (5 samples per second) were used in combination with InSAR and optical satelitte data to produce a detailed kinematic model of the seismic rupture. This modeling shows that the rupture initiated 75km west of Kathmandu, and propagated eastwards over 150km,  unzipping the lower wedge of the locked portion of the MHT. The earthquake ruptured the MHT beneath Kathmandu but  ground acceleration there was actually modest, <20% of gravity, about 75% lower than the level which would have been expected based on standard Ground Motion Prediction Equations. The high frequency waves  (>1hz) were generated from the  northern edge of the rupture.  This observation explains the realtively moderate level of damage in Kathmandu in view of the earthquake's size size and proximity of the rupture.The basin resonated at  a period of 5s due to the trapping of surface waves in the basin. The resonance caused damages to the rare tall buildings in Kathmandu but didn't affect the regular dwellings (generally less than 4 stories high). The study thus shades important new light on the relationship between damages,  site effects and source characteristics.

Learning from this research is being used to revise the building code of Nepal.
